text.0: for jātavedas worthy of our praise will we frame with our mind this eulogy as twere a car.
text.1: for good in his assembly is this care of ours let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.2: the man for whom thou sacrificest prospereth dwelleth without a foe gaineth heroic might.
text.3: he waxeth strong distress never approacheth him let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.4: may we have power to kindle thee fulfil our thoughts in thee the gods eat the presented offering.
text.5: bring hither the Ādityas for we long for them let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.6: we will bring fuel and prepare burnt offerings reminding thee at each successive festival.
text.7: fulfil our thought that so we may prolong our lives let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.8: his ministers move forth the guardians of the folk protecting quadruped and biped with their rays.
text.9: mighty art thou the wondrous herald of the dawn let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.10: thou art presenter and the chief invoker thou director purifier great high priest by birth.
text.11: knowing all priestly work thou perfectest it sage let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.12: lovely of form art thou alike on every side though far thou shinest brightly as if close at hand.
text.13: o god thou seest through even the dark of night let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.14: gods foremost be his car who pours libations out and let our hymn prevail oer evilhearted men.
text.15: attend to this our speech and make it prosper well let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.16: smite with thy weapons those of evil speech and thought devouring demons whether near or tar away.
text.17: then to the singer give free way for sacrifice let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.18: when to thy chariot thou hadst yoked two red steeds and two ruddy steeds windsped thy roar was like a bulls.
text.19: thou with smokebannered flame attackest forest trees let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.20: then at thy roar the very birds are terrified when eatingup the grass thy sparks fly forth abroad.
text.21: then is it easy for thee and thy car to pass let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.22: he hath the power to soothe mitra and varuṇa wonderful is the maruts wrath when they descend.
text.23: be gracious let their hearts he turned to us again let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.24: thou art a god thou art the wondrous friend of gods the vasu of the vasus fair in sacrifice.
text.25: under thine own most wide protection may we dwell let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.26: this is thy grace that kindled in thine own abode invoked with soma thou soundest forth most benign.
text.27: thou givest wealth and treasure to the worshipper let us not in thy friendship agni suffer harm.
text.28: to whom thou lord of goodly riches grantest freedom from every sin with perfect wholeness.
text.29: whom with good strength thou quickenest with children and wealthmay we be they eternal being.
text.30: such agni thou who knowest all good fortune god lengthen here the days of our existence.
text.31: this prayer of ours may varuṇa grant and mitra and aditi and sindhu earth and heaven.
